The first principle is creating space—both physical and emotional. You want to maintain at least two arm lengths distance while keeping your body language open and non-threatening.
What if they keep advancing on you though?
Then you employ lateral movement, never backing straight up because that can feel like retreat. Move at angles while maintaining eye contact and using a calm, lower-pitched voice.
Could you, um, please explain more about, [overly polite] the voice techniques since, well, that seems really important?
Absolutely. So, you want to speak, uh, about 20% slower than normal and, basically, drop your pitch because, you know, higher voices can actually trigger more aggression.

You're right to question that. Matching aggressive energy escalates things further—instead, you want to be the thermostat, not the thermometer, setting the emotional temperature rather than reflecting it.

Document everything but don't engage with the threat directly. Acknowledge their feelings without validating threatening behavior, saying something like "I understand you're frustrated, let's find a solution together."

Crowds complicate things because, well, people perform for audiences and, I mean, feel pressure to save face, so actually, if possible, you want to, er, move the conversation somewhere more private.
